unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Restaurant Promotion: Determine the Probability
question_text:
A new restaurant is trying to attract customers and has decided to run a promotion. During their grand opening celebration, everyone who stops by will be given one ticket which contains an area that can be scratched off to reveal a single prize.
Consider a case where $50\%$ of the tickets reveal a discount, $20\%$ of the tickets reveal a free beverage, $15\%$ of the tickets reveal a free appetizer, $10\%$ of the tickets reveal a free dessert, and the remaining tickets reveal a free entree.
What is the probability that the individual who receives the first ticket will win either a free appetizer or free entree (assume that this individual is able to pick one of the tickets at random)?
solution:
To solve this problem, first find the probability of winning a free entree. We know that the distribution of all possible prizes must add up to $100\%$.

Therefore:

$$p(\text{Entree}) = 100 – 50 – 20 – 15 – 10 = 5\% \text{ or } 0.05$$

Then use the addition rule for mutually exclusive events.

$$p(\text{Appetizer OR Entree}) = p(\text{Appetizer})+p(\text{Entree}) = 0.15 + 0.05 = 0.20$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect since it only represents the probability of winning a free entree.

Choice 'B' is incorrect since it only represents the probability of winning a free appetizer.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because it assumes that the events are independent and that there is a possibility of winning both a free appetizer AND a free entree. This answer choice can be arrived at with the following calculation:

$$p(\text{Appetizer OR Entree}) = 0.15 + 0.05 - (0.15)(0.05)$$

Keep in mind, however, that each ticket reveals a single prize. Therefore, the event of winning a free appetizer and the event of winning a free entree are mutually exclusive. That is, with one ticket, you cannot win both prizes. So, $p(\text{Appetizer AND Entree}) = 0$, NOT $(0.15)(0.05)$

Choice 'E' is incorrect. It could represent the probability of winning only a discount. Alternatively, it could represent the probability of winning any type of food/beverage item.
